title: Sampling Theory
explanation:
Introduction to Sampling

Sampling is the process of converting continuous-time signals to discrete-time signals. It's fundamental to digital signal processing, enabling computers to process real-world analog signals.

Sampling Process

A continuous signal $x(t)$ is sampled at regular intervals $T$ (sampling period):

$x[n] = x(nT)$ for $n = 0, \pm1, \pm2, ...$

Key Parameters:

  • Sampling Period: $T$ (time between samples, in seconds)
  • Sampling Frequency: $f_s = \frac{1}{T}$ (samples per second, Hz)
  • Sampling Angular Frequency: $\omega_s = 2\pi f_s = \frac{2\pi}{T}$ (rad/s)

üí° Sampled signal: $x_s(t) = x(t) \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\delta(t-nT)$

Nyquist-Shannon Sampling Theorem

‚ö†Ô∏è The Most Important Theorem in DSP:

Statement: A bandlimited signal with maximum frequency $f_{max}$ can be perfectly reconstructed from its samples if:

$f_s \geq 2f_{max}$

or equivalently: $\omega_s \geq 2\omega_{max}$

Key Terms:

  • Nyquist Rate: $f_N = 2f_{max}$ (minimum sampling rate)
  • Nyquist Frequency: $f_{Nyq} = \frac{f_s}{2}$ (maximum recoverable frequency)

üéØ Example: Audio CD quality uses $f_s = 44.1$ kHz because human hearing range is ~20 kHz, so $2 \times 20 = 40$ kHz + margin = 44.1 kHz

Aliasing

Definition: When $f_s < 2f_{max}$, high-frequency components appear as lower frequencies (false identities)

Aliasing Formula:

A sinusoid at frequency $f$ sampled at rate $f_s$ appears at frequency:

$f_{alias} = |f - kf_s|$ for integer $k$ that minimizes $f_{alias}$

‚ö†Ô∏è Problem: Aliasing is irreversible - original signal cannot be recovered!

Prevention: Use anti-aliasing (low-pass) filter before sampling to remove frequencies above $f_s/2$

Reconstruction

Ideal Reconstruction: Use sinc interpolation

$x(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}x[n]\text{sinc}\left(\frac{t-nT}{T}\right)$

where $\text{sinc}(x) = \frac{\sin(\pi x)}{\pi x}$

Practical Reconstruction:

  • Zero-Order Hold (ZOH): Hold each sample constant until next sample (step-like)
  • First-Order Hold (FOH): Linear interpolation between samples
  • Digital-to-Analog Converter (DAC): Reconstructs with low-pass filter

Frequency Domain View

Sampling in time domain causes periodic repetition in frequency domain:

$X_s(\omega) = \frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}X(\omega - k\omega_s)$

Implications:

  • Spectrum repeats every $\omega_s$ rad/s (or $f_s$ Hz)
  • If $\omega_{max} < \omega_s/2$: No overlap (good!)
  • If $\omega_{max} \geq \omega_s/2$: Overlap occurs (aliasing!)

Oversampling and Undersampling

Technique Condition Application
Oversampling $f_s \gg 2f_{max}$ Reduces quantization noise, relaxes anti-aliasing filter requirements, used in ADCs
Critical Sampling $f_s = 2f_{max}$ Theoretical minimum, rarely used in practice
Undersampling $f_s < 2f_{max}$ Intentional aliasing (bandpass sampling), used in RF/communications

Bandpass Sampling

For bandpass signals (centered at $f_c$ with bandwidth $B$):

Generalized Nyquist Rate: $f_s \geq 2B$ (not $2f_c$!)

Can sample much slower than $2f_c$ if signal is narrowband

üí° Used in: Software-defined radio, radar, ultrasound imaging

Sampling Rate Conversion

Decimation (Downsampling): Reduce sampling rate by integer factor $M$

  • Keep every Mth sample: $y[n] = x[Mn]$
  • Must low-pass filter first to prevent aliasing
  • New rate: $f_s' = f_s/M$

Interpolation (Upsampling): Increase sampling rate by integer factor $L$

  • Insert $(L-1)$ zeros between samples
  • Low-pass filter to remove images
  • New rate: $f_s' = Lf_s$

Rational Rate Change: Combine: First interpolate by $L$, then decimate by $M$

New rate: $f_s' = \frac{L}{M}f_s$

Quantization

After sampling (time discretization), signals are quantized (amplitude discretization):

Quantization Step: $\Delta = \frac{V_{max} - V_{min}}{2^b}$ where $b$ = number of bits

Quantization SNR: $\text{SNR}_{dB} \approx 6.02b + 1.76$ dB

üí° Each additional bit improves SNR by ~6 dB

Applications

  • Audio: CD (44.1 kHz), DVD (48 kHz), Hi-Res (96/192 kHz)
  • Telephony: 8 kHz sampling (voice bandwidth ~4 kHz)
  • Video: Various rates (24/30/60 fps for images, higher for sensor data)
  • Biomedical: ECG, EEG sampling rates based on signal bandwidth
  • Communications: SDR, OFDM systems, wireless protocols
  • Instrumentation: Oscilloscopes, data acquisition systems

quiz.question: According to the Nyquist-Shannon sampling theorem, what is the minimum sampling rate required for a signal with maximum frequency of 5 kHz?
quiz.explanation: The Nyquist-Shannon theorem states that the sampling frequency must be at least twice the maximum signal frequency: $f_s \geq 2f_{max} = 2 \times 5 = 10$ kHz. This is called the Nyquist rate. Sampling below this rate causes aliasing.

quiz.question: What is aliasing in the context of sampling?
options: High frequencies appearing as lower frequencies due to undersampling
quiz.explanation: Aliasing occurs when the sampling rate is less than the Nyquist rate ($f_s < 2f_{max}$). High-frequency components fold back and appear as lower frequencies. This is irreversible and distorts the signal. It's prevented by using an anti-aliasing low-pass filter before sampling.

quiz.question: What is the Nyquist frequency for a system with sampling rate fs = 1000 Hz?
quiz.explanation: The Nyquist frequency is half the sampling rate: $f_{Nyq} = \frac{f_s}{2} = \frac{1000}{2} = 500$ Hz. This is the maximum frequency that can be unambiguously represented at the given sampling rate. Frequencies above this will alias.

exercises.problem: A signal contains frequency components at 2 kHz, 5 kHz, and 8 kHz. What is the minimum sampling rate required to avoid aliasing? If we sample at 12 kHz instead, what frequency will the 8 kHz component appear at?
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • Signal frequencies: 2 kHz, 5 kHz, 8 kHz
  • Undersampling case: $f_s = 12$ kHz

Step-by-Step Solution:

(a) Minimum Sampling Rate:

Step 1: Find maximum frequency

$f_{max} = 8$ kHz

Step 2: Apply Nyquist theorem

$f_s \geq 2f_{max} = 2 \times 8 = 16$ kHz

Minimum sampling rate = 16 kHz

(b) Aliasing at fs = 12 kHz:

Step 1: Check which frequencies alias

Nyquist frequency: $f_{Nyq} = f_s/2 = 12/2 = 6$ kHz

2 kHz < 6 kHz ‚úì (no aliasing)

5 kHz < 6 kHz ‚úì (no aliasing)

8 kHz > 6 kHz ‚úó (aliasing occurs!)

Step 2: Calculate aliased frequency for 8 kHz component

$f_{alias} = |f - kf_s|$ where we choose k to minimize $f_{alias}$

Try k=1: $f_{alias} = |8 - 12| = 4$ kHz

Try k=0: $f_{alias} = |8 - 0| = 8$ kHz (but > $f_{Nyq}$)

Step 3: Final answer

The 8 kHz component will alias to 4 kHz

Result: Sampled signal appears to contain 2 kHz, 4 kHz, and 5 kHz (wrong!)

exercises.problem: An analog signal x(t) = 3cos(40œÄt) + 2sin(100œÄt) is sampled at fs = 60 Hz. (a) Identify the frequencies in Hz. (b) Determine if aliasing occurs. (c) Find the aliased frequencies if any.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • $x(t) = 3\cos(40\pi t) + 2\sin(100\pi t)$
  • Sampling frequency: $f_s = 60$ Hz

Step-by-Step Solution:

(a) Identify frequencies:

For $\cos(\omega t)$: $\omega = 2\pi f$

First component: $\omega_1 = 40\pi$ rad/s

$f_1 = \frac{\omega_1}{2\pi} = \frac{40\pi}{2\pi} = 20$ Hz

Second component: $\omega_2 = 100\pi$ rad/s

$f_2 = \frac{\omega_2}{2\pi} = \frac{100\pi}{2\pi} = 50$ Hz

Frequencies: 20 Hz and 50 Hz

(b) Check for aliasing:

Nyquist frequency: $f_{Nyq} = \frac{f_s}{2} = \frac{60}{2} = 30$ Hz

Required Nyquist rate: $f_N = 2 \times 50 = 100$ Hz

20 Hz < 30 Hz ‚úì (below Nyquist frequency)

50 Hz > 30 Hz ‚úó (above Nyquist frequency)

‚úó Aliasing OCCURS for 50 Hz component

(c) Calculate aliased frequency:

For 50 Hz component with $f_s = 60$ Hz:

$f_{alias} = |50 - k \times 60|$ for integer k

Try k=0: $|50 - 0| = 50$ Hz (above $f_{Nyq}$)

Try k=1: $|50 - 60| = 10$ Hz (below $f_{Nyq}$) ‚úì

Aliased spectrum: 20 Hz (original) + 10 Hz (aliased from 50 Hz)

‚ö†Ô∏è The sampled signal will appear as: $3\cos(40\pi t) + 2\sin(20\pi t)$ - wrong!

exercises.problem: A digital audio system samples at 48 kHz with 16-bit quantization. (a) What is the Nyquist frequency? (b) Calculate the theoretical SNR. (c) If we want to downsample to 16 kHz, what decimation factor M should be used?
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • Sampling rate: $f_s = 48$ kHz
  • Quantization: $b = 16$ bits
  • Target rate: $f_s' = 16$ kHz

Step-by-Step Solution:

(a) Nyquist Frequency:

$f_{Nyq} = \frac{f_s}{2} = \frac{48000}{2} = 24000$ Hz

Nyquist frequency = 24 kHz

(b) Quantization SNR:

Formula: $\text{SNR}_{dB} \approx 6.02b + 1.76$

$\text{SNR}_{dB} = 6.02 \times 16 + 1.76 = 96.32 + 1.76 = 98.08$ dB

Theoretical SNR ‚âà 98.1 dB

This is approximately 16 √ó 6 dB = 96 dB, plus ~2 dB overhead

(c) Decimation Factor:

Step 1: Calculate required decimation

$M = \frac{f_s}{f_s'} = \frac{48000}{16000} = 3$

Step 2: Verify

New rate: $f_s' = \frac{48}{3} = 16$ kHz ‚úì

Decimation factor M = 3 (keep every 3rd sample)

Important: Before decimation, must low-pass filter at 8 kHz (new Nyquist frequency) to prevent aliasing!
